so I'm going to turn over to Eric who's going to talk about what we actually did to implement the solution thank you so

rapid minor are in our studio and I think SPSS this usage was entirely

at the end of the semester we looked at the data and so the first thing we looked at was Amazon's own usage data on

our physical computer labs have at least a single 21 inch LCD on every

Charlottesville when you need to complete a homework assignment so we looked at how could we provision a

developed last summer again brand-new program so the curriculum was being developed at the same time as we were building these workspace images but the

what we learned in the pilot we dumped every application that we could think of into this workspace image the idea was

or you don't have a text editor you don't have a file manager we basically put every application they could use
throughout the 12 months of this program into the work space unlike with our pilot this wasn't a bonus this is
required for them to use this program doesn't really work without some kind of virtualized option so again new program
we're trying to develop workspaces the one of the biggest decisions we have to make is the running mode you know Amazon
offers two options you can pay by the hour or you can pay monthly and sort of that all-you-can-eat scenario where it
doesn't matter how many hours you use a new program doesn't have any existing usage data are these students going to
use workspaces for five hours a month are they going to use it for a hundred hours a month we had to make some educated guesses but we really do
you know we really don't have the data to fall back on to see hey what's going to happen here again the faculty were
pretty insistent that these had to be high-powered workstations and so we made the decision to go with the power
hardware bundle and workspaces which includes four virtual CPUs and 16 gigs of RAM we went back and forth on this
with the faculty a little bit but they felt that that was the right balance between price and performance so on that
hardware bundle the break-even point is 89 hours a month if your users are using their workspaces more than 89 hours per
month you should just pay for the always-on running mode it doesn't matter at that point if you're gonna use less
than 89 hours per month you want to go to auto stop where you disconnect the users after one hour of idle time you
sort of stop the meter and then the next time they connect to workspaces you know the billing picks up again so
at the launch of the program our best guess was that students would not be hitting that 89 hours a month breaking point and we decided to go with the auto
stop running mode and so after a couple of months we decided to look at the data
again my pie charts are fighting me today but what we found is that students averaged about 33 hours per month so we
were well below that break-even point on average we also had about 7% of our
students that were going over that point that we're using 90 hours or more in a month and we even had a couple students
that were in triple digits that we're using over a hundred hours a month this is powerful hardware this these are
powerful applications all of the students in this program are working professionals this is an executive program and so it raises the issue is
all of this usage academic usage you know many of our software licenses you
know the terms and conditions tell us that this software is to be used for academic purposes only we don't really
have a great way to enforce that we're relying on the students own you know sort of personal honor code you know but
if they're using tableau to produce some visualizations for a presentation at work on Monday morning instead of using
it for class work we don't have a technical way to stop that so the first
couple of months of the program you know we had some growing pains again new program first time we're using workspaces in production first time
we're using workspaces is something that's required for the curriculum and so the biggest problem we saw in the beginning was that the workspaces client
would occasionally refuse to connect students had installed properly their credentials were correct they would
attempt to log on and workspaces would just tell them unable to connect we mostly saw this issue when the entire
class was trying to connect at the same time so these students have online classes via zoom every Tuesday and
Thursday evening at 7 o'clock p.m. and what we saw is that some students would be unable to connect at that time now in
client services and helpdesk we always assume that everything is the users problem the users fault they must be doing something wrong and this behavior
gets reinforced when you have the same five or six people saying well I can't connect to workspaces but the rest of
the class and the faculty member is in just fine we started to think now it's something on the user's device their
Wi-Fi at home isn't robust enough to support what we're doing etcetera etc etc but these users told us that you
know at other times non class times they were able to connect just fine so we developed a theory that you know
maybe the always-on running mode would would be a solution maybe autostop was causing problems corrupting the VMS
causing issues with our VM so even though it had some financial implications we moved all of our workspaces to the always-on running mode
so this please students and faculty in one-dimension log in times were much faster you know again the machine is
always running so as soon as they log in you know they get to their desktop within seconds which is great but again
we have this issue where some workspaces and it tended to be the same five six seven students were unable to connect so
aw support worked with us and eventually we got to this point where we figured out that there was an internal limit on
the number of power workspaces that could be launched at any one time the limit was technically twenty AWS
explained to us that that was really more of a soft cushion we'd certainly had more than twenty workspaces up and running at one time but we'd never had
forty you know 33 34 35 seemed we were where we hit our cap we were seeing the
same students report issues because it's the same five or six students that tend to show up late for class every Tuesday
on Thursday so you know there are some students that if it's a 7 o'clock class are going to be firing up their
workspace at 6:58 701 703 and those tended to be the
students that you know tried to get in when we had hit this workspaces cap once
the problem was identified 80lbs was super quick to remove that cushion and from then on there were you know there
were no issues having all 40 of our students logged on at the same time but this this discussion then led us to a
couple of refinements so you know after that after that cap was removed we drop
back down to the auto stop running mode so that the machines were shutting themselves down after an hour of idle
time and so the login times were still a little bit slow and again it's most prevalent when all the students are sitting down for class either an online
session or an in-person session the faculty member is waiting like go ahead and fire up workspace is an open tableau
and it's not a long time but it's maybe two three four minutes whether the faculty member is standing up there sort
of impatiently impatiently tapping his foot so we developed this cloud watch rule in conjunction with Amazon to say
look we know that for our zoom classes for our online classes students are sitting down every Tuesday and Thursday
at 7 o'clock p.m. they're going to be firing up their workspaces every Tuesday every Thursday at 7 o'clock p.m. why
don't we just develop a rule that auto launches all of these workspaces ahead of time say at 6:40 p.m. and if you go
back to the idea of you know this is a physical computer lab replacement you know this is equivalent to going into a
computer lab right and walking down the rows and pushing the on button on every single workstation that's in effect what
we're doing with this cloud rock cloud watch rule we're firing up the machines at 640 in advance of a 7 o'clock class
the students open their client the machine has already turned on they log in and they get to their desktop in
about 3 or 4 seconds this change made the students much happier we also saw an
issue where we'd have workspaces that would fall into an unhealthy status you know for those of you familiar with the
AWS workspaces console you know you want to look at your workspaces and see either they're stopped they're shut down
or they're started you know that nice green word that tells you that up and running you don't want to see the orange unhealthy status and we have some
students repeatedly get into this unhealthy status we think you know because they were shutting down the
client improperly because they had a break in their network connection because their machine
ran out of battery and they didn't have it plugged into the wall there was some sort of non graceful shutdown of the workspaces client happening which put
the workspace itself into an unhealthy status so again working with AWS support
we came up with a simple solution we just developed a rule that watches for any machines in the MSB a group that are
in an unhealthy status if it finds one it reboots it problem solved we run this
every two hours is sort of a you know a balance between trying to catch the machines when they aren't healthy but
not necessarily paying for hourly usage that we're not using but this could easily run you know every 15 minutes
every five minutes every one minute these are the kind of you know growing pains that again first year of the
program these things are not wholly unexpected I'm not going to say that there weren't some frustrations at time
but it's a new program curriculum still under development using a service that we'd not used as a mission-critical
service in the past and at AWS has been a you know a great partner for us in that sort of helping us refine these
issues you know in a lot of ways the first year of this program has really been a you know even though it's in
production has been somewhat of a beta test and we're going to move forward with this and kind of figure out you know how do how to refine this process
and and smooth out some of these bumps in the road for future classes so I'm gonna turn this back over to Brian who's

learned some things from this 18-month experiment and we'll pass those on
because this is where we we had some problems so first and foremost we wanted these workspaces to act as if they were
on UVA grounds we wanted them to be on our domain we wanted them to have access to sequel servers and other resources
and file servers so as a result we needed robust network tunnels from us to the AWS cloud that was apparently a

stable robust double VPN network so that we could we could use our workspaces as
if they were sitting in Charlottesville the second lesson we're still doing is talk to the faculty despite having all
these capabilities and all the software we still have faculty going workspaces and taking class time to
install things locally an extreme case of that as a faculty member buying 60 terabyte flash drives to
distribute datasets the conversation we got those returned but you know we could
have put that on a network drive and saved a lot of a lot of fuss so the faculty are very used to how they teach
